Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Flexible Network Inference
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists have been studying many natural systems by viewing them as networks, a term used to describe collections of entities and their interactions. Networks are ubiquitous in many fields, including epidemiology, economics, sociology, genomics and ecology, to name a few. A number of statistical models have emerged over the last two decades to describe network data. One common type of model is the latent space model, where each entityâ€™s behavior is governed by its position in some unobserved (latent) space, and if we knew these positions, we could fully describe the statistical behavior of the network. While these models have been useful in many problems, real systems tend to be more complicated. The goal of this project is to fill this gap between models and reality by developing network analysis methods that still perform well even when the model does not fully match the data.

The specific aims of this project are to improve our understanding of existing network analysis methods under model misspecification, heterogeneous noise, and incomplete or missing data, and to develop novel network methods that are robust to these sources of error. We consider both these problems under one unified framework that represents the adjacency matrix of a network as its expectation plus entry-wise noise, which encompasses most popular network models. Within this framework, the project will examine the effects of model misspecification on downstream inference, both for global inference tasks (e.g., network-level summary statistics) and local inference (e.g., node-level statistics). One core goal of the project is developing bootstrap and resampling algorithms for networks, two extremely useful tools in classical statistics that do not yet have full network analogues. Another core goal is developing more general notions of community membership and node similarity, allowing the extension of robust algorithms to a broader collection of network models. Finally, the methods developed will be extended to the analysis of multiple networks. Taken together, these tools will substantially expand the toolbox of network techniques, while accounting for the realities of noisy and incomplete network data and imperfect network models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed project addresses critical topics in network analysis and the broader area of graph analysis. It studies these problems under a unified model where the observed data is in matrix form and admits the form of a low-rank signal matrix subject to a noise matrix. This model encompasses many widely used network models, including the Erdős-Rényi model and stochastic block models and their variants. Thanks to the unified model setting, the project has a broad scope, allowing it to address fundamental theoretical and methodological challenges in statistical data analysis in network research, offering significant benefits to statisticians and practitioners working with network data in fields such as social sciences, health sciences, economics, and marketing.

The research explores both local and global inference problems under the unified model assumption. For global inference, it introduces a new universal test for determining and estimating the true rank of the underlying low-rank mean matrix, where the rank often has practical interpretations, such as the number of communities in social networks. Accurate rank estimation, supported by statistical guarantees, can improve the accuracy of subsequent data analysis and reduce bias. For local inference, the project proposes a novel method for testing the similarity of a given group of individuals in the network, addressing the practical question of clustering individuals in a network with a statistical significance guarantee. This test works under broad model settings with mild assumptions, making it broadly applicable in various practical applications.

Beyond these methodological contributions, the project advances random matrix theory toolkits for network and graph model researchers. It develops non-asymptotic entry-wise expansions for the leading eigenvalues and eigenvectors of large adjacency and Laplacian matrices, crucial for network and graph inference. Given the importance of the Laplacian matrix in graph neural networks, these results can also be greatly helpful in enhancing the theoretical understanding of complex machine learning algorithms for network and graph data. In addition, the PI has been developing methods and theories in the multiple/dynamic network setting and incorporating network analyses into causal inference research.  

The PI has integrated the results and outcomes from this project into a PhD-level course, which is very popular and attracts students from diverse disciplines, including statistics, economics, machine learning, and engineering. Two PhD students and two postdoctoral researchers, including a female scholar, have been trained through this project. The PI has also presented the project’s outcomes at major statistics conferences and various departmental seminars. These talks have been very well received with positive feedback. Papers summarizing these results and outcomes have been posted on PI's personal webpage.
